column3: I think the name of this option (`--enable-lowmem`) is confusing. Given that, I'd assume it lowers *run time* memory requirements.
@laanwj Good point! What would be a more appropriate name?
What is the point in compiling releases with `-g` by default. Has this ever helped to debug an issue, considering that they are optimized with `-O2`?

> What is the point in compiling releases with -g by default. Has this ever helped to debug an issue, considering that they are optimized with -O2?\n\nThe debug info for releases has been useful for me at times to get backtraces.

> How is this different from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/7f985d6c8159f377b685ec2f404f733bdae6ac58/doc/build-unix.md#memory-requirements\n\nThe end result in terms of max RSS for the troublesome files is roughly the same (on my machine at least!), but this PR speeds up the total build time by -11% whereas the linked GCC garbage collection tweak slows down the total build time by sever
Thanks for the explanation. Do you think it makes sense to update the documention to mention `fvar-tracking` instead of adding a "configure wrapper" around `fvar-tracking`?

@laanwj 

> > What is the point in compiling releases with -g by default. Has this ever helped to debug an issue, considering that they are optimized with -O2?

> The debug info for releases has been useful for me at times to get backtraces.

Instead of switching the default from `-g -O2` to `-O2`: what about going with `-g -O2 -fno-var-tracking` as the default? (`-fvar-tracking` would
